content: The "Advance Directive Promotion Act of 2008" includes provisions for improving policies related to advance directives, Medicare coverage for end-of-life planning consultations, a national information hotline for end-of-life decision-making, and increasing awareness of the importance of end-of-life planning. The "Advance Directive Promotion Act of 2008" aims to improve policies related to the use and portability of advance directives. The "Advance Directive Promotion Act of 2008" amends Section 1866(f) of the Social Security Act to include the content of advance directives in medical records presented by individuals. The "Advance Directive Promotion Act of 2008" requires providers to include advance directives in a patient's medical record and allow individuals to discuss related issues with a trained professional. Additionally, providers must honor valid advance directives executed outside the state. Providers must give effect to a valid advance directive executed outside the state to the same extent as one executed under the state's law. They can presume the validity of an out-of-state advance directive unless there is evidence to the contrary. The amendments allow for the administration of health care treatment prohibited by state laws, preempting any inconsistent state laws. These provisions do not override state laws that offer greater flexibility or deference to a patient's wishes. Effective dates apply to provider agreements under title XVIII. The amendments extend the application of provider agreements under title XVIII and State plans under title XIX of the Social Security Act, with an effective date specified by the Secretary of Health and Human Services, not later than 1 year after enactment. State plans requiring legislation to meet additional requirements will not be considered non-compliant solely for not meeting these requirements before the first day of the first calendar quarter after the State legislature's first regular session. The Act specifies that provider agreements and State plans under title XVIII and XIX of the Social Security Act will be extended until the first calendar quarter after the State legislature's first regular session following enactment. Each year of a 2-year legislative session is considered a separate regular session. Medicare will cover end-of-life planning consultations as part of an initial preventive physical examination. Medicare covers end-of-life planning consultations, defined as discussions between a physician and an individual about preparing advance directives for future health care decisions in case of incapacity. The importance of preparing advance directives for future health care decisions, situations where they may be relied upon, benefits of developing an end-of-life plan, and resources for understanding state requirements. The amendments made by this section apply to initial preventive physical examinations furnished on or after January 1, 2009. SEC. 4. NATIONAL INFORMATION HOTLINE FOR END-OF-LIFE DECISIONMAKING AND HOSPICE CARE. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will establish a clearinghouse and a 24-hour toll-free hotline to provide information on advance directives, end-of-life decision-making, and hospice care services. This will be funded through grants, contracts, or interagency agreements. The Administrator may designate an existing clearinghouse and 24-hour toll-free telephone hotline for information on advance directives, end-of-life decision-making, and hospice care services. If no such entity is appropriate, a new clearinghouse and hotline may be established. Increasing awareness of end-of-life planning through programs to educate on advance directive planning issues. This includes advance directive education campaigns under Title III of the Public Health Service Act. The Secretary will conduct a national public education campaign to raise awareness about planning for care near the end of life, improve understanding of health care wishes, and emphasize the importance of advance directives like living wills. The Secretary will allocate funds for grants to public or nonprofit entities for education campaigns on hospice and palliative care, advance directives, and end-of-life planning. The Secretary authorizes grants for education campaigns on hospice and palliative care, advance directives, and end-of-life planning. Grants are awarded for a 3-year period, with $25,000,000 authorized for appropriations.
